title: 112_hr6427
content: The Act may be cited as the "Capitalizing Workforce Development Act of 2012" and includes a Job Training Resources Grant Program. The "Capitalizing Workforce Development Act of 2012" includes a Job Training Resources Grant Program that provides funds for job training programs to purchase, renovate, construct, or lease real property for self-sustaining job programs. The term 'qualified self-sustaining job program' refers to a program that offers job training and employment services to individuals with employment challenges, without requiring federal funds for program expenses. Applicants can still participate in other federal programs. Grants under this program prioritize job training and placement services. The Secretary gives priority to eligible applicants with successful experience in establishing self-sustaining job programs or with local organizations awarded grants under section 413(h)(3)(A). Eligible applicants include national organizations. The term 'eligible applicant' in section 413(h)(3)(A) includes national organizations, States, political subdivisions, Indian tribes, or tribal organizations. Grant conditions and requirements include job placement performance goals. The grant conditions and requirements for eligible applicants include job placement performance goals for self-sustaining job programs. The grantee will receive grant funds and the performance assessment dates for goal achievement will be set by the Secretary. The Secretary will protect the Federal Government's interest in real property purchased, renovated, constructed, or improved with funds from the grant. The Secretary will protect the Federal Government's interest in real property purchased, renovated, constructed, or improved with grant funds. Eligible applicants receiving funds must distribute them among local organizations for self-sustaining job programs. Out of $200,000,000 appropriated for grants in fiscal year 2013 for self-sustaining job programs, a penalty is imposed for failing to meet job placement goals under the Social Security Act. If a recipient of funds for self-sustaining job programs fails to meet job placement goals, they must repay the funds to the Treasury over a 10-year period without accruing interest. The recipient of funds for job programs failing to meet placement goals must repay the funds over 10 years without interest. They can also comply with goals set by the Secretary instead of making payments. If a state fails, they must repay funds as well. The Secretary may reduce grants to states failing to meet penalties for job program funds, with exceptions to state penalty limitations. The Social Security Act is amended to exclude certain penalties from the state reasonable cause exception. The Social Security Act is amended to exclude certain penalties from the state reasonable cause exception. [SEC. 3. OFFSET TO ENSURE PAYGO COMPLIANCE.]
